div.p: This element is conceptually a part of BIOGRAPHY PRODUCTION . It captures the first significant writing activity, published or otherwise, of the subject. It should not be used for publications unless there's strong evidence that the publication actually sprang from the actual earliest writing activity. This element should contain a full sentence spelling out if possible (and tagging) the title of the work, its date of creation of publication, and its TGENRE. Avoid tagging other dates while still within this element, to ensure that the one tagged date refers to the first literary activity. This element should occur in a CHRONSTRUCT if possible; using it will put the CHRONSTRUCT into MILESTONE on the OVERVIEW screen. It has no mandatory or optional sub-elements or attributes.

div.codeblock: <PFIRSTLITERARYACTIVITY>Joanna Baillie's first play, Arnold, is, lost.</PFIRSTLITERARYACTIVITY> <PFIRSTLITERARYACTIVITY>Eleanor Ann Porden was planning an essay periodical in <DATE>1815</DATE> when her long poem, The Veils or the Triumph of Constancy, written at age 16, appeared.</PFIRSTLITERARYACTIVITY>

<PFIRSTLITERARYACTIVITY>The future Mary Wortley Montagu seems to have circulated her writings among a group of young women including probably Mary Monck. She copied them in two surviving albums, from one of which pages were cut out, apparently following a reprimand for writing.</PFIRSTLITERARYACTIVITY>
